title: 110_s2982
content: The Act titled "Reconnecting Homeless Youth Act of 2008" emphasizes the importance of providing services to homeless youth with a positive youth development approach. This approach ensures safety, belonging, self-worth, independence, and interpersonal relationships. The Act also amends the services provided under the Basic Center Program. The Youth Act (42 U.S.C. 5711) is amended to include safe shelter for up to 21 days. Funding amounts are increased for fiscal years 2009 and 2010, ensuring a minimum allotment equal to the previous year. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include an emergency preparedness plan and transitional living grant program eligibility criteria are updated to include grants, agreements, or contracts for services. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include an emergency preparedness plan and update transitional living grant program eligibility criteria to allow for grants, agreements, or contracts to provide services for up to 540 days, or in exceptional cases, 635 days. Additionally, a youth in the program can stay until their 18th birthday if they have not reached that age by the end of the 635-day period. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include an emergency preparedness plan and update transitional living grant program eligibility criteria. The term 'exceptional circumstances' is defined as situations where a youth would benefit significantly from additional time in the program. Grants for research evaluation, demonstration, and service projects are also prioritized under the amendments. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to prioritize grants for research evaluation, demonstration, and service projects. Amendments include updating transitional living grant program eligibility criteria and defining "exceptional circumstances" for extended program participation. Additionally, changes involve enhancing access to quality health and behavioral health care, as well as providing programs for educational and workforce outcomes. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to prioritize grants for programs assisting youth in obtaining safe housing, with a focus on diverse populations. Applicants with experience working with homeless youth are given priority. Part D of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to require a periodic estimate of youth homelessness every 5 years, using social science research methods to determine the incidence and prevalence of runaway and homeless individuals aged 13 to 26. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act now requires a report every 5 years estimating youth homelessness among individuals aged 13 to 26. The report includes survey results and interviews to assess the characteristics and barriers faced by this population in obtaining housing, health insurance, services, and support. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act requires a report every 5 years estimating youth homelessness among individuals aged 13 to 26. The report includes survey results and interviews to assess the characteristics and barriers faced by this population in obtaining housing, health insurance, services, and support, as well as sexual abuse prevention programs and performance standards. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act mandates the establishment of performance standards for entities receiving grants under specific sections. The Secretary must consult with relevant organizations to develop these standards within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will integrate performance standards into grant processes for programs under specific sections. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on grant-making processes under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The Comptroller General will review grant application documents and peer review processes for grants under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure clarity and understanding for applicants. The oversight of funding determinations by Department of Health and Human Services staff, response timeframe for grant applicants, and implementation of technical assistance programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act will be reviewed. The Homeless Youth Act requires a report on the impact of programs on grant applications. Definitions of "homeless youth" are amended to specify age criteria. The Homeless Youth Act requires a report on the impact of programs on grant applications and amends definitions of "homeless youth" to specify age criteria, including compliance with State or local laws for higher maximum age limits in child and youth-serving facilities. The Homeless Youth Act specifies age criteria for "homeless youth" including those under 22 years of age or those over 22 years who started their stay before turning 22. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act defines "runaway youth" as individuals under 18 who leave home without permission. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is increased to $140,000,000 for fiscal year 2009. The authorization of appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is updated to $140,000,000 for fiscal year 2009. Amendments include changes to funding allocations for fiscal years 2010-2013 and adjustments to specific paragraphs within the Act. The authorization of appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is updated to $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 and such sums as may be necessary for fiscal years 2010-2013.
